item.title: Notes on Institutions, Contract & Information
item.description: Literature Adverse Selection (Hidden Information) Lemon Market Moral Hazard (Hidden Action) Timing Benchmark Limited Liability Agent Offers Contract Literature Contract Theory Game Theory (multi-stage games) Institutions and Economic Theory (very general and theoretical) Institutional Economics: An Introduction (Groenewegen, J. & Spithoven, A. & Van den Berg, A.) Firms, contracts, and financial structure (incomplete contract) Adverse Selection (Hidden Information) Lemon Market Moral Hazard (Hidden Action) Return: \(v\) Effort level: \(e\) Techonology: \(F(\hat{v} \ | \ e) = Pr(v\leq \hat{v} \ | \ e)\) Cost: \(c(e)\) Contract: \(t\) Principle’s payoff: \(v - t\) Agent’s payoff: \(t - c(e)\) Reservation utility: \(\underline{U} = 0\) Incentive compatility constraint (IC): agent chooses the level of effort that maximizes their own utility Participation constraint (PC): agent accepts the contract only if the expected utility exceeds other alternatives (their reservation utility) Timing Principal offers contract Agent accepts or rejects Agent chooses \(e\) (unobservable) \(v\) is realized (verifiable) Payment \(t\) is made Benchmark First best solution: \[\begin{aligned}e^{FB} &= \text{argmax} \ E[v \ | \ e] - c(e) \\ &= \begin{cases} p(e)\cdot v_h + \big( 1-p(e)\big) \cdot v_l & v\in\{ v_l, v_h\} \\ \int_{v_l}^{v_h} v\cdot f(v|e)dv & v\in [v_l, v_h]\end{cases}\end{aligned}\] where \(p(e) = Pr(v = v_h \ | \ e)\) Franchising contract: \(t(v) = v-a\) (may be positive or negative) Agent’s problem \[\begin{aligned}\max_e && E[t(v) \ | \ e] - c(e) &= E[v \ | \ e] - a - c(e) \\ && e^* &= e^{FB} \end{aligned}\] Principle’s payoff \[\begin{aligned}v-t(v) &= a \\ &= E[v \ | \ e^{FB}] - c(e^{FB})\end{aligned}\] Limited Liability Limited liability: \(t\geq 0\) Return: \(v\in \{v_h, v_l\}\) Effort level: \(e\in \{ e_h, e_l\}\) Technology: \(\begin{cases}Pr( v = v_h \ | \ e = e_h ) = e_h \\ Pr( v = v_h \ | \ e=e_l ) = e_l \\ e_l < e_h \end{cases}\) Cost: \(\begin{cases}c(e_h) = c \\ c(e_l) = 0 \end{cases}\) First best solution \(e^{FB} = e_h\) when \[\begin{aligned} e_h v_h + (1-e_h )v_l - c &\geq e_lv_h + (1-e_l)v_l - 0 \\ (e_h - e_l)(v_h - v_l) &\geq c\end{aligned}\] \(e^{FB} = e_l\) otherwise Second best solution Contract: \(\begin{cases}t(v_h) = t_h \\ t(v_l) = t_l \end{cases}\) When principle implements \(e = e_h\) \[\begin{aligned}\max && &e_h(v_h - t_h) + (1-e_h)(v_l - t_l) \\ (IC) && &e_h t_h + (1-e_h )t_l - c \geq e_l t_h + (1-e_l )t_l - 0 \\ (PC) && &e_h t_h + (1-e_h )t_l - c \geq \underline{U} = 0 \\ (LL) && &\begin{cases}t_h \geq 0 \\t_l \geq 0 \end{cases}\end{aligned}\] Lemma: \(\begin{cases}t_h = \frac{c}{e_h - e_l} \\ t_l = 0\end{cases}\) is a solution Agent’s expected payoff (LL rent): \[\begin{aligned}e_h t_h + (1-e_h )t_l - c &= e_h \cdot \frac{c}{e_h - e_l} - c\\ &= \frac{e_lc}{e_h - e_l}\end{aligned}\] Principle’s expected payoffi: \[\begin{aligned}e_h (v_h - t_h) + (1-e_h )(v_l - t_l) &= e_h (v_h - t_h) + (1-e_h )v_l \\ &= e_h v_h - e_ht_h + (1-e_h )(v_l - t_l) \\ &= e_h v_h - \frac{e_hc}{e_h - e_l} + (1-e_h )v_l \end{aligned}\] When principle implements \(e = e_l\) Contract: \(t_h = t_l = 0\) Agent’s expected payoff: 0 Principle’s expected payoff: \(e_l v_h + (1-e_l )v_l\) Principle wants to implement \(e = e_h\) when \[\begin{aligned} e_h v_h - \frac{e_hc}{e_h - e_l} + (1-e_h )v_l &\geq e_l v_h + (1-e_l )v_l\\ (e_h - e_l)(v_h - v_l) &\geq \frac{e_hc}{e_h - e_l}\end{aligned}\] When \(c\leq (e_h - e_l)(v_h - v_l) < \frac{e_hc}{e_h - e_l}\), the first best solution is feasible but not attained Agent Offers Contract Contract: \(\begin{cases}t_h = v_h \\ t_l = v_l \end{cases}\) First best solution is attained Agent’s expected payoff: \(e_h v_h + (1-e_h )v_l\) Principle’s expected payoff: 0 Restrictions of contractual freedom may be welfare-enhancing

item.title: Notes on Game Theory
item.description: Extensive Game, Perfect Information Strategy Subgame Chance Moves Bargaining textbook 1: (OR) A Course in Game Theory textbook 2: (BM) Fun and games Reference: Carlos Hurtado’s lecture notes Extensive Game, Perfect Information OR 6.1 Reference Set of players: \(N\) Set of histories: \(H\) History (sequence): \(h = (a^k)_{k=1}^K\) Initial history: \(\emptyset\in H\) \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\), \(K>L\implies (a^k)_{k=1}^L\in H\) \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\) for all \(K\in\mathbb{N} \implies (a^k)_{k=1}^{\infty}\in H\) Set of terminal histories: \(Z\) Terminal history: \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\) is terminal if exists no \((a^k)_{k=1}^{K+1}\in H\) Set of (possible) actions: \(A(h): \{ a \ | \ (h,a)\in H\}\) Action: \(a\in h\) for some \(k\in K\) History of length \(k+1\): \((h,a)\) Player function: \(P: (H\backslash Z)\to N\) Player to move after history \(h\): \(P(h)\) Initial player: \(P(\emptyset)\) with \(a^0\in A(\emptyset)\) Second player: \(P(a^0)\) with \(a^1\in A(a^0)\) Preference relation: \(\succsim_i\) defined on \(Z\) Extensive Game with Perfect Information: \[Γ = \langle N,H,P,(\succsim_i)\rangle\text{ or }\langle N,H,P\rangle\] Finite game: \(|H|<\infty\) Finite horizon: \(K <\infty\) for all \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\) Rank of game: \(\max K\) for all \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\) Length of game: \(l(Γ)\) is the length of longest history in \(Γ\) Exercise (slides P13)
